duck: Isomorphism (Gestalt psychology), a correspondence between a stimulus array and the brain state created by that stimulus
Group isomorphism, in mathematics, a mapping that preserves the group structure
Isomorphism (biology), a similarity of form or structure between organisms
Isomorphism (sociology), a similarity of the processes or structure of one organization to those of another
Ring isomorphism, in mathematics, a mapping that preserves both the additive and multiplicative structure of a ring
Graph isomorphism, in mathematics, a mapping that preserves the edges and vertices of a graph
isomorphism definition: the quality or state of being isomorphic.
Isomorphism theorem, in mathematics, theorems that describe the relationship between quotients, homomorphisms, and subobjects
Isomorphism, in mathematics, logic, philosophy, and information theory, a mapping that preserves the structure of the mapped entities

wiki.text:
In abstract algebra, an 'isomorphism'<ref>From the Greek: isos "equal", and
morphe "shape"</ref> is a bijective homomorphism.<ref></ref> Two mathematical
structures are said to be 'isomorphic' if there is an isomorphism between them.

In essence, two objects are isomorphic if they are indistinguishable given only
a selection of their features, and the isomorphism is the mapping of the set
elements and the selected operations between the objects. A named isomorphism
indicates which features are selected for this purpose. Thus, for example, two
objects may be group isomorphic without being ring isomorphic, since the latter
isomorphism selects the additional structure of the multiplicative operator.

In category theory, an 'isomorphism' is a morphism in a category for which there
exists an "inverse" with the property that both id<sub>X</sub>}} and
id<sub>Y</sub>.}}<ref></ref>
wiki.title: isomorphism
